issue.title: Fix compilation when GLFW_BUILD_WAYLAND is on

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
should fix #2016

Problems found:
1. [These lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/CMakeLists.txt#L86-L91) should produce a source file (.c) not a header. So there's no need to include these files in `wl_init.c`
2. After that, hitting undefined symbols around [these lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/wl_platform.h#L85-L123). I don't quite know the purpose of these lines but removing these lines don't seem to cause any harm
3. wayland-client [include paths are included](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/CMakeLists.txt#L174) but its libraries are not linked

I have tested the change by first building with `GLFW_BUILD_WAYLAND=On` then, adding this line to `cursor.c`
```
    glfwInitHint(GLFW_PLATFORM, GLFW_PLATFORM_WAYLAND);
```
then testing the cursor program with the mutter compositor on Ubuntu 18.04

body:
I found what seems to be glaring problems.

1. [These lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/CMakeLists.txt#L86-L91) should produce a source file (.c) not a header. So there's no need to include these files in `wl_init.c`
2. Even after I got around that, I started hitting undefined symbols around [these lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/wl_platform.h#L85-L123). I don't quite know the purpose of these lines but removing these lines don't seem to cause any harm
3. wayland-client [include paths are included](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/CMakeLists.txt#L174) but its libraries are not linked 

There are some things (especially 2) which I might be missing context for, but I'm going to PR anyway as it seems to be working for me.

PR is up at #2032. Please check.

> I found what seems to be glaring problems.

These things were done on purpose in dffe203c178ecea44a0c3d52a7b62c45a6615944 to allow the Wayland libraries to be on demand loaded at runtime. This hopefully also addresses point 3.

> 1. [These lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/CMakeLists.txt#L86-L91) should produce a source file (.c) not a header. So there's no need to include these files in `wl_init.c`

They are included as header files so we can redirect the Wayland core function calls in them to our own functions pointers without needing to modify wayland-scanner or its output.

> 2. Even after I got around that, I started hitting undefined symbols around [these lines](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/src/wl_platform.h#L85-L123). I don't quite know the purpose of these lines but removing these lines don't seem to cause any harm

Because GLFW is often used as a static library, these macros ensure that our object files don't export symbols that could interfere with other Wayland code during linking.

Since these structs are not static and also grow over time, if the linker ever picks the wrong one when combining GFLW and other Wayland code compiled with a different version of the protocols, it would result in very difficult to diagnose bugs.

The slightly hairy approach of 65617b9abaca3d5edb8c52a292d13a8755778a57 in the `wayland-scanner-compatibility` branch seems to work on my copy of Ubuntu 18.04, without losing the benefits of dynamic loading.
This should be fixed now with 65617b9abaca3d5edb8c52a292d13a8755778a57. Thank you for reporting this!
